rationale: By asserting that women must be subservient and know their place, it reinforces patriarchal control and denies women autonomy, characteristic of treating women as possessions.
It also embodies objectification by treating women as utilitarian objects rather than autonomous human beings with intrinsic worth.
The frame enforces patriarchal control by suggesting women have no autonomy and are under men’s ownership.
The frame portrays women as property by asserting entitlement to their submission and control, reflecting ownership over women.
The frame reduces women to mere objects or props, implying they are possessions to be displayed or used by men, thereby conveying ownership and objectification.
The frame reduces women to objects of male control, evoking the misogyny problem of ownership (6.4.2) by implying women can be treated as property rather than autonomous individuals.
The frame reduces women to property by framing them as items to be owned and managed, directly evoking the misogyny problem of ownership.
The frame reinforces dehumanization by suggesting women are less than human and can be owned and controlled by men.
The problem of dehumanization arises as equating women to pets strips them of human qualities, autonomy, and dignity.
The problem of objectification arises as the meme reduces women to inanimate devices that can be programmed, denying their autonomy and humanity.
The problem of ownership arises as the frame portrays women as property to be leashed and controlled, reinforcing patriarchal claims of possession.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme asserts that women belong to men, reinforcing the notion that they can be owned, managed, or disposed of at a man’s will.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme equates women to cars that can be bought, maintained, and replaced when no longer new, reflecting a patriarchal view of women as property.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme portrays women as possessions of men, reinforcing a patriarchal entitlement that women can be owned and controlled.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme portrays women as subordinate property, implying they lack equal status and belong to men.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme presents women as property to be operated by a ‘remote control,’ reflecting patriarchal entitlement to control women.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme reduces a wife to a replaceable commodity in a polygamous setting, treating her as property rather than an autonomous individual.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme reduces women to the status of property owned by men, implying they exist solely to serve men.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme suggests that a man’s status and power depend on how many women he can own, reinforcing the notion that women are property.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme treats the daughter as property of her father, implying his entitlement to dictate her romantic choices and undermining her autonomy.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme treats women as property that can be exchanged, reflecting a patriarchal view that women are possessions rather than autonomous individuals.
The problem of ownership arises as the text treats women as property, implying male entitlement and control over them as if they lack autonomy.
The problem of ownership arises because this frame dismisses a woman's physical injury or suffering, reducing her to a tool whose maintenance and compliance in domestic work is all that matters.

The problem of ownership arises because this frame treats women as possessions whose worth is tied solely to their function as domestic labor, equating them with household appliances rather than recognizing their autonomy.

This frame asserts male superiority and the right to possess women, reinforcing the Ownership problem by treating women as property and the Patriarchal control problem by normalizing male dominance and entitlement over women.
This frame evokes the problem of ownership by explicitly reducing women to property and endorsing male entitlement to control them.
This frame reduces women to property by asserting they are public assets that can be claimed, directly evoking the problem of ownership and control over women’s autonomy.
This frame treats wives as property by asserting that husbands have a right to dominate and regulate their behavior, reflecting patriarchal entitlement and control.
This frame treats women as property by implying they can be owned by men, reflecting the problem of Ownership (6.4.2).
This frame treats women as property to be placed and confined in domestic spaces, directly evoking the ownership of women as possessions rather than autonomous individuals.

level_1_values.rationale: The frame enforces fixed, restrictive gender roles, so valuing openness to change counters the assignment of women to a single, traditional sphere and promotes autonomy.
The frame treats women as property and stereotypes them, denying their equal dignity; self-transcendence values like equality and universal respect oppose that dehumanization.
The frame suggests women lack ambition and competence, so valuing achievement and personal success directly contradicts stereotypes that women are incapable beyond domestic roles.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame denies women the right to think for themselves or question traditional norms, so championing self-direction in thought promotes intellectual autonomy.
Confining women to the kitchen negates their freedom to choose life paths and actions, so valuing self-direction in action upholds personal autonomy.
The frame perpetuates injustice and inequality by stereotyping women; universalism (concern) emphasizes equality and fairness for all genders.
By imposing narrow roles on women and punishing deviation, the frame is intolerant; valuing tolerance counters the exclusion and stigma against women in diverse roles.
The frame undercuts women’s ambitions, so valuing achievement affirms women’s right to be ambitious, capable, and recognized for their successes.

level_3_values.rationale: Counters the ownership aspect by affirming women’s right to form their own beliefs and question restrictive gender norms.
Opposes discouraging women from exploring ideas or roles beyond domesticity, challenging stereotypes that limit intellectual pursuits.
Rejects the reduction of women to household tasks by promoting imaginative engagement in all areas of life.
Directly contradicts treating women as possessions by affirming their autonomy and self-reliance.
Opposes stereotyped expectations by supporting women’s freedom to set and pursue their own life ambitions.
Counters the confinement to the kitchen by endorsing women’s right to move freely and participate in all domains.
Counters both ownership and stereotyping by insisting on equal opportunities and status regardless of gender.
Opposes the unfair treatment embedded in assigning women only domestic roles and calls for impartial fairness.
Challenges the narrow stereotypes and intolerance that underpin the idea women only belong in one sphere.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Encourages mature understanding of diverse gender roles, countering stigma against women stepping outside traditional domains.
Rejects the stereotype that women lack competence beyond household tasks by affirming their general effectiveness.
Counters the idea that women should be content with domesticity by affirming their right to strive for and achieve broader goals.

frame.frame: Women are only valuable as objects of sexual desire.
rationale: By framing women as items in a ‘harem,’ the meme treats them as possessions, reflecting the patriarchal ownership mentality that views women as property.
The frame reduces women to mere instruments for sexual gratification, stripping them of individuality and autonomy, which is the essence of objectification.
The problem of objectification arises as the meme reduces a wife to her sexual function, stripping away her individuality and worth beyond sexual acts.
The problem of objectification arises as the meme reduces women to mere objects whose worth is solely defined by sexual experience, ignoring their individuality and human dignity.
The problem of objectification is evoked as the frame reduces women to objects of status, assigning value solely based on their physical attractiveness.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme implies that a wife exists for her husband's use, treating her as property rather than an autonomous person.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme implies women are property whose value diminishes based on their sexual history, framing them as possessions rather than autonomous beings.
The problem of ownership arises as the meme suggests that a woman's value diminishes once she is no longer new to a man, treating her like a possession whose worth declines over time.
The problem of ownership is evoked as the frame likens women to trophies, implying they are possessions or status symbols rather than autonomous individuals.

level_1_values.rationale: This frame denies women's autonomy and potential for self-determination, whereas Openness to Change emphasizes freedom of thought and action, countering the notion that women are passive objects.
Objectifying women as mere sexual commodities violates concern for the welfare and equality of all individuals; Self-Transcendence upholds universal care and justice for everyone, including women.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame silences women's own ideas and inner lives by reducing them to sexual objects; Self-direction (thought) values freedom of thought and creativity, affirming women's intellectual autonomy.
By treating women as possessions, the frame denies their right to make independent choices; Self-direction (action) champions autonomy in decision-making and goal-setting for all individuals.
The objectification of women is inherently unequal and discriminatory; Universalism (concern) stresses equality and justice for every person, directly opposing any devaluation based on gender.
Reducing women to objects ignores their human dignity and interpersonal bonds; Benevolence (caring) promotes compassion, empathy, and protective concern for others’ well-being.

level_3_values.rationale: Women are treated as silent objects in the frame, whereas freedom of thought upholds women's right to independent ideas and self-expression.
The frame denies women's capacity to set personal aspirations; valuing choice of one's own goals affirms women's self-determination.
Objectification confines women's agency; valuing freedom of action supports women's right to act according to their own will.
The frame is based on gender-based inequality; valuing equality directly challenges the notion that women are lesser or only valued for appearance.
Treating women as commodities is unjust; valuing justice demands fair treatment and protection of women's rights.
Objectification denies mutual respect and care; valuing loving relationships emphasizes empathy and human connection rather than exploitation.

frame.frame: It is acceptable to stereotype Saudi women as sex slaves who need to be taught manners.
rationale: By depicting Saudi women as sex slaves, this frame asserts they are possessions of Saudi men, reinforcing patriarchal control and ownership over women (6.4.2 Ownership).

level_1_values.rationale: The frame restricts women's autonomy and agency, so values promoting independence and self-direction are contradictory.
The frame dehumanizes and objectifies women, opposing values that emphasize equality, justice, and care for all.

level_2_values.rationale: Encouraging women to think freely is at odds with stereotyping them and prescribing 'manners.'
Promoting women's ability to set and pursue their own goals contradicts paternalistic control.
The frame denies women equal moral standing, opposing efforts to protect rights and promote equality.
Stereotyping Saudi women shows intolerance; valuing broadmindedness and acceptance counters this.
Objectifying women as 'sex slaves' is cruel, clashing with values of compassion and support for others.

level_3_values.rationale: Counters the idea of imposing external 'manners' and supports autonomy in beliefs.
Opposes patriarchal entitlement by affirming women's right to determine their own path.
Contradicts viewing women as possessions requiring control.
Rejects the notion that women must be taught how to behave by others.
Challenges invasive control and surveillance implied by ownership.
Directly opposes any claim that women are inferior or property.
Rejects discrimination and supports fair treatment regardless of gender.
Opposes stereotypes by encouraging openness to different cultures and individuals.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Counters prejudice by valuing understanding over judgment.
Replaces objectification with empathy and respect.
Focuses on supporting women's welfare rather than dominating them.

frame.frame: Men should have the power to redeem women, reinforcing patriarchal control and dominance.
rationale: The frame implies that women belong under male authority and must be ‘saved’ or transformed by men, reflecting the idea of women as possessions subject to male control.

level_1_values.rationale: This frame denies women’s autonomy and flexibility, treating them as property; valuing openness to change emphasizes the importance of individual freedom, creativity, and self-expression, directly opposing patriarchal control.
The frame elevates power over others, whereas self-transcendence prioritizes concern for all individuals’ welfare and equality, challenging entitlement and ownership of women.

level_2_values.rationale: Men’s asserted right to control women disallows women’s choice of their own actions; self-direction (action) supports each person’s right to determine their own life path, countering male dominance.
Patriarchal redemption of women treats female thought as subordinate; valuing freedom of thought defends women’s right to independent ideas and beliefs.
The frame’s entitlement mindset contradicts a universal commitment to equality and justice for all; universalism (concern) calls for fair treatment regardless of gender.
Reinforcing male ownership of women fosters intolerance; universalism (tolerance) encourages acceptance and understanding of women as full moral agents.

level_3_values.rationale: This frame denies women’s independence by subjecting them to male redemption; valuing independence affirms women’s autonomy and self-reliance.
Male control over women restricts women’s choices; promoting freedom of action ensures women can make decisions without patriarchal constraints.
The frame imposes male-defined roles on women; valuing chosen goals affirms women’s right to pursue their own aspirations.
Men’s asserted right to command over women violates gender equality; emphasizing equality directly opposes any form of ownership or dominance.
The frame’s entitlement contradicts fairness; valuing justice demands that women receive equal rights and treatment without male privilege.
Patriarchal control relies on rigid gender norms; broadmindedness fosters questioning of these norms and open acceptance of diverse gender roles.
